Keywords

　Keywords are those that have the highest precedence during expression evaluation. These include the following, in addition to the usual numbers and identifiers (tokens).

true/false

　true and false are treated as integer values with values of 1 and 0, respectively.

　Avoid comparing true and false with other expressions. For example, do not write if (true! = getBoolean ()), instead, write if (! getBoolean ()). In this expression, "0 is false", "non-zero is true", not "1 is true", and since TJS2 does not have a Boolean type, it is an automatic number ← → logical type conversion. This is because the type conversion is not performed.

void

　void literally means "nothing". It is used in situations to indicate "nothing", for example: return types, etc. Not to confuse with null
　A newly created value is automatically assigned with void
　If this value is treated like a string, it will be empty (""). If treated as an integer, it will be 0.

　For void-to-void comparisons, it is recommended to use the === or !== (identifiers) operator.

null

　null indicates a variable that it is an object that doesn't represent anything. Not to confuse with void.
　Trying to access a null object will cause an error.
　If you change the context to null using the incontextof operator, the function will run on the context at the point where it was called.

Usage:
    var objmethod = obj.method;
    objmethod(); //Executed on the context of  obj 
    objmethod = objmethod incontextof null; Context changed to  null 
    objmethod(); //executed on  this  (i.e., the context at the location of the call)

Infinity

　As by the name, it denotes "infinity". -Infinity is used to represent negative infinity.

NaN

　NaN means "Not a Number". Whenever an invalid calculation is done, the result becomes NaN.

super

　super represents the superclass of the class within the methods/properties of the class. Attempting to reference it outside of a class method/property or in a class with multiple inheritance will result in an error.

global

　global represents a global object. It provides access to variables declared outside of all blocks, classes, and functions that are not methods of a class.


Usage:
    var v;
    function test(v)
    {
        global.v=v;  //Sets the argument  v  to  v  in the  global  object.
    }

this

　this usually represents the object of the class itself within the methods and properties of the class.
　The "context" specified explicitly or implicitly at the time of the call is specified as this.

functions used in expressions

You can use the　function keyword to write a function in an expression. See Functions.

Arrays in expressions

You can use [] to write an object of the Array class in the expression on the fly. See the Array class.

Dictionaries in expressions

　You can use %[] to write an object of the Dictionary class in an expression on the fly. See the Dictionary class.
